My amendment will strengthen our national security and save billions of tax-payer dollars. I hope my colleagues will join me in this critically important effort to address the modern nuclear arms race and prevent the unnecessary expenditure of billions of taxpayer dollars.

But more fundamentally, our nuclear posture is centered on a principle of deterrence rather than dominance. Regardless of Chinese nuclear capabilities, our strategic forces are sufficient to deter a nuclear attack on the U.S. or its allies.
The deployment of GBSD will not impact our deterrence calculus since it will not alter the overall numbers of ground-based ballistic missiles.

Opponents will also claim GBSD is needed since China is rapidly expanding its ground-based silo
ICBMs. Even with China’s reported expansion of its nuclear forces, our arsenal still dwarfs China’s.

Opponents of my amendment will falsely claim that GBSD is more cost-effective. A 2017 CBO report showed that it would cost $37 billion less to life extend the Minutelam III than developing and deploying the GBSD through 2036.

GBSD would require billions of taxpayer dollars to be spent unnecessarily. It also precipitates a modern nuclear arms race and predicates our nuclear modernization efforts on a strategy of dominance rather than deterrence.

THREAD: Today, the House is voting on my #NDAA amendment to pause the development of the Ground Based Strategic Deterrent (#GBSD) missile program. The Air Force has said the Minuteman III missile, which GBSD would replace, could be life extended instead of being replaced.

In fact, under the current plan, many Minuteman III
missiles will need to be life extended through the mid-to-late 2030s while they are gradually replaced by the GBSD. My amendment simply pauses GBSD development for one year while @POTUS prepares his Nuclear Posture Review (NPR).

President Biden has made the right decision to end a war that should have concluded years ago and not pass this conflict along to a fifth president. I appreciate his leadership and am firm in my commitment to help every U.S. citizen and Afghan ally return to safety today.

I've served on the House Armed Services Committee for 11 years. I have received countless briefings on the situation in Afghanistan, led delegations to the region, and studied the conflict and history at length.

Evacuation flights are moving steadily, and the work is being done to bring people to safety. My staff and I are also encouraging any constituent who has family in the region that needs to be brought to safety to contact my office at CA03.casework@mail.house.gov.

Today, our focus is on evacuating U.S. citizens and Afghan allies from the region safely and as quickly as possible. President Biden is sending additional troops to facilitate the departure of Americans and allied civilian personnel to safety.
We owe them a debt of gratitude and must recognize the work they’ve done to abate the threat of terrorism to our homeland. We must always honor their service and sacrifice.

This situation is difficult for American veterans and everyone who has spent the last 20 yrs in Afghanistan. Those who risked their lives and paid the ultimate cost for their service did so with dignity and honor while carrying out the policies and missions of four presidents.
The Afghanistan government wasn’t overthrown—it simply disappeared. President Biden was clear that we would not stay and force American soldiers to nation-build and fight indefinitely.

While the events that transpired over the last 3 days happened more precipitously than expected, they have confirmed that the decision to drawdown was the right one. Afghanistan’s political leadership fled the country, and its military collapsed without even attempting to fight.

The latter would put thousands of additional American troops in harm’s way and thrust our nation into the third decade of conflict in Afghanistan. 

The President made the right decision.

Those who were silent while the previous administration pursued a full withdrawal and are now castigating the current administration are coated in hypocrisy. President Biden was faced with the choice of following through on that agreement or redoubling our efforts to fight
If he had not made this decision, there would be no ceasefire. No agreement protecting our forces. No status quo of stability without casualties.

When President Biden took office, there was a ceasefire agreement in place negotiated by President Trump and the Taliban. President Trump agreed to a full withdrawal of U.S. forces by May 1. President Biden extended this deadline until September.

THREAD: President Biden has a consummate understanding of the history of Afghanistan. He considered every fact and contingency and made the correct decision to drawdown the U.S. presence in the region. He was not willing to pass this war on to a fifth president.
